instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Green & Orange Light / No Power / Low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Apologies if this turns out to be something really stupid, I'm operating on not a lot of sleep here.

I've got a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that came in, no power. The board is immaculate, I've been over it several times and no signs of any corrosion at all, anywhere.

Some readings:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 8.58
PPBUS_S5_HS_* - 8.58
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> - 18.19
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> - 18.19
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.42
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.33
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5.02
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> - 1.159
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> - 0.00
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.33
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> - 0.00
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 3.33
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> - 3.33
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - 3.33
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> - 0.04

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> is the obvious one out here, but I can't find anything wrong on any components connected. Nothing that jumps out to me as a short to ground anywhere.

Anyone able to give me a nudge in the right direction? Thank you!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Green & Orange Light / No Power / Low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Meant to say, bench supply is drawing 0.080a.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Green & Orange Light / No Power / Low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Post diode mode to ground on L7520; red probe at ground.
Also post voltage for pin 4 of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>.
Be sure <CAPACITOR>C7524</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R7545</RESISTOR> are both good.

Do you get <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> high level?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Green & Orange Light / No Power / Low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 51246"]Post diode mode to ground on L7520; red probe at ground.[/QUOTE]
0.430

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 51246"]Also post voltage for pin 4 of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>.[/QUOTE]
0.917v

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 51246"]Be sure <CAPACITOR>C7524</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R7545</RESISTOR> are both good.[/QUOTE]
Bingo, looks like there might be an issue with <RESISTOR>R7545</RESISTOR>, I'll replace.

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 51246"]Do you get <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> high level?[/QUOTE]
0.941v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Green & Orange Light / No Power / Low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> also missing?
Check if reacts when you trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> signal; use <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads for this.
Are you using original Magsafe 2 (two) charger?
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> will stay low, if not.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Green & Orange Light / No Power / Low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Replaced <RESISTOR>R7545</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7524</CAPACITOR> to no affect (though certainly <RESISTOR>R7545</RESISTOR> did need replacing.

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 51266"]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> also missing?[/QUOTE]

Yes, 0.03v

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 51266"]Check if reacts when you trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> signal; use <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads for this.[/QUOTE]

Doesn't appear to. I notice a tiny fluctuation in the power supply draw, 0.79 becomes 0.80 and then drops again.

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 51266"]Are you using original Magsafe 2 (two) charger?[/QUOTE]

Original genuine MagSafe 2 cable on a DC power supply. No discernible difference using a full genuine MagSafe 2 charger.

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 51266"]<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> will stay low, if not.[/QUOTE]

Can confirm 0.00v with DC supply, 3.33 with Genuine charger, other readings appear unaffected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Green & Orange Light / No Power / Low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Board will NOT start with low level at <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>.
Why do you insist with desk power supply???

Post <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> levels.
Check for any reaction (drop pulse) at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.
BTW, do you get 3V at <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>?

Check if start in SMC bypass.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Green & Orange Light / No Power / Low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 51272"]Board will NOT start with low level at <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>.
Why do you insist with desk power supply???[/QUOTE]

- It's a genuine cable, which I thought was what was important
- It's not been an issue before
- At least two other <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boards this week alone and they've worked fine with this setup
- I don't want shitty boards killing ?79 genuine chargers

But now that I know there's the potential for problems, I'll keep an eye out. Every day is a school day.

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 51272"]Post <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> levels.[/QUOTE]

3.33v & 3.41v


[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 51272"]Check for any reaction (drop pulse) at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.[/QUOTE]

Yes, drops when triggered. I missed the exact value, but looks to be about a 1v drop.


[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 51272"]BTW, do you get 3V at <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>?[/QUOTE]

3.41

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 51272"]Check if start in SMC bypass.[/QUOTE]

Unfortunately not.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Green & Orange Light / No Power / Low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Re-tested <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> from a different point with the DC supply and it's fine, it's at 3.3v. I was testing on <TRANSISTOR>Q3000</TRANSISTOR> and I think the contact point was too fine for a reliable multimeter probe connection. Apologies.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Green & Orange Light / No Power / Low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"Yes, drops when triggered."
Are you sure no pulse at all at any <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals???
That points to bad PCH, or some if its signals is not good.

Check all 4 (four) RTC signals (page 12).
Also check <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Green & Orange Light / No Power / Low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 51279"]"Yes, drops when triggered."
Are you sure no pulse at all at any <SIGNAL>PM_SLPSX_L</SIGNAL> signals???
That points to bad PCH, or some if its signals is not good.[/QUOTE]

I can't detect anything at all, but that might just be the tools I have access to not being quick enough so I can't be 100%.

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 51279"]Check all 4 (four) RTC signals (page 12).[/QUOTE]

<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.33v
<SIGNAL>PCH_CLK32K_RTCX1</SIGNAL> - 0.37v
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> @ 3.33v
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 0.00v

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 51279"]Also check <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.[/QUOTE]

3.24v & 3.41v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Green & Orange Light / No Power / Low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 0.00v"
Solve that, or board never starts...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Green & Orange Light / No Power / Low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 51311"]"<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 0.00v"
Solve that, or board never starts...[/QUOTE]

Looks like <RESISTOR>R1303</RESISTOR> at fault, will replace and report back.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Green & Orange Light / No Power / Low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> @ 3.33v

Still no signs of life. Perhaps just a knackered PCH?

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Green & Orange Light / No Power / Low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>

threads.message: Try now all the things before mentioned.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Green & Orange Light / No Power / Low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: No change, unfortunately, everything is as it was reported previously.
